text.p: English second division soccer team Bournemouth won a stay of execution in their battle for survival on Thursday when the British tax authorities adjourned their attempts to have the club wound up.
The club's bank said the petition had been put on hold until May 15, allowing the south coast club to play out the season.
The club went into receivership in January with debts of 4.5 million pounds ($7.2 million), around half of which is owed to the bank. About 250,000 pounds ($400,000) is due to the tax authorities.
The job of the receiver is to sell assets as necessary in order to recover debts.
Fans of the club have raised over a million pounds ($1.6 million) in a bid to rescue the club and turn it into Britain's first "community owned" team.
Bournemouth is one of a number of lower division clubs facing a bleak future as more and more of the income from television deals and merchandising flows to the 20 teams in the elite premier league.
